subject: Fansensor: Support ast26xx pwm/tach
commitMessage:
Fansensor: Support ast26xx pwm/tach

Add new fantype for ast26xx tach driver.
Use pwm-fan driver to setup ast26xx pwm driver for easier usage.
User must define pwm-fan node in dts as below

pwm-fanX {
	compatible = "pwm-fan";
	.......
};
refer Documentation/devicetree/bindings/hwmon/pwm-fan.txt for details

and Connector in EM configuration
"Connector": {
    "Pwm": X,
    ......
}

where X is integer

Tested: On Facebook Bletchley (ast26xx) Platform with 1 fan

root@bletchley:/sys/class/leds# busctl set-property xyz.openbmc_project.FanSensor /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm/Pwm_1 xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value Value d 20
root@bletchley:/sys/class/leds# busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.FanSensor /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/FAN0_TACH_IL xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value
NAME                             TYPE      SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE                             FLAGS
.MaxValue                        property  d         25000                                    emits-change
.MinValue                        property  d         0                                        emits-change
.Unit                            property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value.Uni... emits-change
.Value                           property  d         3189                                     emits-change writable
root@bletchley:/sys/class/leds# busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.FanSensor /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/FAN0_TACH_OL xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value
NAME                             TYPE      SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE                             FLAGS
.MaxValue                        property  d         25000                                    emits-change
.MinValue                        property  d         0                                        emits-change
.Unit                            property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value.Uni... emits-change
.Value                           property  d         3006                                     emits-change writable

Signed-off-by: Howard Chiu <howard.chiu@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: Ifda89310590c9d914fa0a302df412fead807daa8
Signed-off-by: Potin Lai <potin.lai@quantatw.com>

Change has been successfully merged
More details please.  You're adding several things to the config.  They should be at least mentioned here.
I will add it into commit log of the next patchset
These enums are not descriptive enough.  Both the 2500 and 2600 use PWMs.  Please revise.
like aspeedPWMFan? since ast2600 used pwm-fan driver to setup ast2600 pwm driver which was different from ast2500 which used aspeed pwm driver directly
This function is already much larger than it should be, this is adding 80 more lines.  Please refactor and simplify.
Make it be a function?
I'm not understanding why these need to be completely different paths.  Can you expand a bit?

Let me explain it with sysfs
root@bletchley:/sys/class/hwmon# ls -la
...
hwmon6 -> ../../devices/platform/ahb/ahb:apb/1e610000.pwm_tach/1e610000.pwm_tach:tach/hwmon/hwmon6
...
hwmon15 -> ../../devices/platform/pwm-fan0/hwmon/hwmon15

you can see that tach driver is under /ahb:apb but pwm-fan is under /pwm-fan where the pwm1 belongs to

With ast2500 pwm-tach driver, the fan*_input and pwm* are at the same directory, but Aspeed separated them into ast2600-tach and ast2600-pwm driver for ast26xx SoC

ast2600-pwm driver followed the new pwm arch of kernel, user has to assign the base frequency manually via sysfs ABI,so Aspeed recommended to setup ast2600-pwm driver with pwm-fan driver which user can assign the base frequency with dts property.
Is there a ast2600 specific reference?

pwm-fan driver is created by Samsung.
However, ast2600-pwm driver followed the new arch of kernel, user has to set frequency divisor via sysfs ABI.
So Aspeed Billy suggested used pwm-fan driver to setup ast2600-pwm , which is very similar with current usage.
magic naumber 7 - what is expected patch format? Is this aspeed 2600 pwm driver only?

7 is the length of string "pwm-fan".
I use pwm-fan driver to setup ast2600-pwm driver and the node in DTS is named with "pwm-fanX", where the X is what we are looking for here.
the ast26xx should support redundancy also, right?

I don't know what is the "redundancy sensor" here.
There are only fan*_input in ast2600-tach directory and one pwm1 in each pwm-fan* directory.

root@bletchley:/sys/devices/platform/pwm-fan0/hwmon/hwmon15# ls
device     name       of_node    power      pwm1       subsystem  uevent

root@bletchley:/sys/devices/platform/ahb/ahb:apb/1e610000.pwm_tach/1e610000.pwm_tach:tach/hwmon/hwmon6# ls -l
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Dec  9 02:11 device -> ../../../1e610000.pwm_tach:tach
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan1_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan2_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan3_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan4_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan5_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan6_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan7_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 fan8_input
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 name
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Dec  9 02:11 of_node -> ../../../../../../../../firmware/devicetree/base/ahb/apb/pwm_tach@1e610000/tach
drwxr-xr-x    2 root     root             0 Dec  9 02:11 power
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Dec  9 02:11 subsystem -> ../../../../../../../../class/hwmon
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Dec  9 02:11 uevent

findPwm == connector->second.end() but type is ast26xx will go into the condition.
Does not seem right, line 424 will not work

My fault, I should remove this line because I added the new property in the previous patch.
I eventually removed it and use the present "Pwm" instead.

Given that the chip we're targeting is known at compile time, why does this need to be in the EM configuration at all?  Can't we just check sysfs for one or the other and configure the appropriate one?

I go through previous discussion, Howard explained the sysfs structure difference between ast25xx & ast26xx before (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/49253/7..9/src/FanMain.cpp#b402)

Adding new fantype will be easier to find correct pwmPath, I guess this is Howard's idea.

Probably can do without adding new fantype.
We get pwm filepath with origin method, if file not exist, try use getPwmfanPath to find it.

or please let me if I misunderstand your comment.

> I go through previous discussion, Howard explained the sysfs structure difference between ast25xx & ast26xx before (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/49253/7..9/src/FanMain.cpp#b402)
> 
> Adding new fantype will be easier to find correct pwmPath, I guess this is Howard's idea.
> 
> Probably can do without adding new fantype.
> We get pwm filepath with origin method, if file not exist, try use getPwmfanPath to find it.

Sure, that's closer to what I would expect, and would be a lot less code.

> 
> or please let me if I misunderstand your comment.
Done
Remove tabs.
tabs are literal required by the kernel though, in this context, right?
Ack
Was this tested in ast2500 system? to check for backward compatibility?

Is it listed?  Probably wasn't tested.

I'm not sure how we can expect everyone to have every piece of hardware.

Ack. 
Can we mention where it was tested? AST2600 is the obvious answer.
But please mention that in commit message. Since this code is directly targeted at that.
Will mention tested on AST2600 in commit message.
Done
Format commit message, wrap line on 80 character or less.

I don't think we conform to this for literals copied into the 'tested' section.  If you don't want the details in the tested, we can remove them, but the output of busctl is going to be pretty ugly to try to reformat to 80 characters.
Ack
Potin, you are taking over this patch for Howard, correct?

Yes, I am taking over it.
Sorry for late reply, I am still try to catch up entire discussion history...

keep aspeed as it is and add new ast26xx at end of enum, 
If you want to change aspeed name take it as a new patch on top of existing one.

Why do you suggest this?  There is a concrete difference in how the PWM driver exposes itself between these two pieces of hardware, right?

I suppose it is "2400+2500".  Do we need to codify that somehow in the enum name?
Don't take me wrong here, I am not against the idea of changing aspeed to ast25xx. But if we are doing that let it be two commits or clearly explained in commit message.
Ack
else if?
Why would you expect a meaningless else?  83 doesn't have one.  Most linters would complain about it.
Since we are calling return from the if conditions, I think we can keep it as it is.
Ack
Clean up magic numbers 7 and 10.
will change it
Done
Question: what is the logic behind assigning std::vector<fs::path> to fs::path?

This is an instance out of the vector, isn't it?  See 114.

Maybe we should short-circuit return here instead of an assign?
Got it, I got confused by pwmfanPath and pwmfanPaths.
Ack

Reorder so that if(fanType == FanTypes::ast25xx) comes first,
This way it will be easier to compare the diff.
Ack
Much simpler!
This is looking much better already.  Just a bunch of minor cleanup stuff to do, then this should be fine.

please prefer const char* or std::string_view to #defines for strings like these, to maintain type safety.

Also, this #define is only used in a single place in code.  Please just inline the string in the one method that uses it rather than declaring it at global scope.
Done
why does this need to be a raw string?  Seems like it could've been a normal string?
Done
Should this be an exact match on a specific part of the string, rather than a search within the string?
agree with you, I changed it to ends_with()

ends_with has the same problem if two nodes get declared with the same postfix (ie, pwm-fan and my-pwm-fan).  This has burned us several times in the past.  Split the string on the patterns you're expecting and do exact matches.  I think in this case you want to use std::filesystem::path::filename()

Agree.
Changed to use filename() to find exact matched name.
Done
nit, there are a number of variables in this that treat "pwm fan" as a single word.  these should be camcelcased as pwmFanIndex.  Please fix all occurrences of this.
no longer exist in new patch set
please prefer to use std::from_chars in new code.
once you break up the string into pieces for the comment on line 116, this can use one of the string pieces instead of indexing into the string.
no longer exist in new patch set
agree with you, please have a check with new patch set
Done
Done

This seems like a strange way to have the branch.  should the code from lines 420 to here be included as part of the getPwmfanPath method, considering that they are also getting the pwm fan path?  Also, fs::exists here is very similar in behavior to the findFiles call on line 111.  Could they be deduplicated so both types of fan take the same path?

In original driver (ast25xx & ast24xx), each pwm file has it own index, and all in same hwmon folder

Ex:
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon0/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon0/pwm2
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon0/pwm3
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon0/pwm4


But in pwn-fan driver, the pwn file are separate into different hwmon folder, and pwm fail always called "pwm1", 

Ex:
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon10/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon7/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon8/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon9/pwm1

So I couldn't find a better rule to apply both types, unless I can know it using pwm-fan at earlier stage (before finding pwmFile).

for enable portion (pwmX_enable), it looks like pwm-fan does not have this file, I moved enable portion after get pwmPath, and skip it if using pwm-fan
For json file that has: "Pwm": 0, this line would be false even with the new driver. So the type will not be detected correctly.

<But in pwn-fan driver, the pwn file are separate into different hwmon folder, and pwm fail always called "pwm1", 

Ex:
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon10/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon7/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon8/pwm1
/sys/class/hwmon/hwmon9/pwm1

< for pwm-fan, the id here correspondsto the name of pwm-fan folder under sysfs, which defined in dts file.

I don't see pwm-fan folder in your example

The getPwmfanPath() is finding all pwm file (pwm1), then reading actual path of "device" in same folder.
If the pwm file is created by pwn-fan driver, then device is a link which link to /sys/devices/platform/pwm-fanX

root@bletchley:~# ls -l /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon10/
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Jan 19 06:50 device -> ../../../pwm-fan0
-r--r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Jan 19 06:50 name
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Jan 19 06:50 of_node -> ../../../../../firmware/devicetree/base/pwm-fan0
drwxr-xr-x    2 root     root             0 Jan 19 06:50 power
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Jan 22 00:59 pwm1
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Jan 19 06:50 subsystem -> ../../../../../class/hwmon
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root          4096 Jan 19 06:50 uevent

root@bletchley:~# ls -l /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon10/device
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root             0 Jan 19 06:50 /sys/class/hwmon/hwmon10/device -> ../../../pwm-fan0
I understand now. Thanks
I wonder if we should be ignoring this portion of the string?  It seems like we're hardcoding SOC specific information that we shouldn't be.
SOC specific info removed
Lets do this in another patchset.

move remove soc part to new patch
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/50713
Done
This feels like it's abusing findFiles() for a 0-or-1 result. Why not iterate though all of the 'pwm[0-9]+' matches?
this is the function specific for searching pwm file generate by pwm-fan driver, and only create one pwm file (pwm1) for each pwn-fan node.
Please don't ignore errors.
I'm not sure that answers andrews question.  Why not iterate pwm[0-9]?
change to R"(pwm\d+)"
change to R"(pwm\d+)"
Changing to that lookup doesn't change the fact that you've ignored an error.

Sorry for missing this.
Put a if condition to check return value of findFiles.
Please have a check with PS17
Done
Done
does it need to be pwm+1 similar to line414?

Same, it's searching pwm-fanX folder.
User need to passing correct id defined in dts file
Ack
No need for this variable, if this is changed to else {}
Done

I pushed an idea as an RFC that I had that might help make this patch easier to write:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/50430

Could you help to review it please?
This skips creation of tach sensor, it that the correct behavior?
Thanks for notice, removed in PS18
LGTM
looks like this branch can never be hit anymore with how you've made these changes.

Sorry of missing this. This also removed in new patch
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/50713
Done
@PL - has there been any progress on this work?

Mark done/ack for previous comments.

Please note, this patch is depends on Aspeed ast2600 PWM driver support (not merged yet)
https://lore.kernel.org/all/20211130055933.32708-1-billy_tsai@aspeedtech.com/

> Please note, this patch is depends on Aspeed ast2600 PWM driver support (not merged yet)

Hi Potin, I understand this needs the unmerged code from Aspeed in order to work (for those not paying close attention, they haven’t gotten merge approval for their AST2600 driver yet but it has gone through many revisions and they are actively revising it), but can you confirm that it also doesn’t break anything to merge as-is?  My understanding is that as long as the sysfs entries don’t show up this code has no effect. So, it is safe to merge right now, right?

Yes, if the sysfs entries not exist, it just won't show add any fans.

It will be grateful if someone could also tested on platforms which using ast2500 or others, just to make sure the change doesn't break origin method.
Log message here if no PWMs are found?
Done
Can you roll this logic into the getPwmFanPath method please?  Using a function called getPwmFanPath, but only in certain conditions makes this logic a lot harder to read.

Done

getPwmfanPath() is for searching pwmX file which exported by pwm-fan driver, so I add getPwmPath() which includes both `origin method` & `pwm-fan method`.
Don't this branch need to stop execution of this method when it handles this error?  Otherwise this method continues with an empty pwmPath, which doesn't seem right.
Done

If I'm reading this correctly (which it's possible I'm not) I'm a little confused why this else is here.  The code I'm reading is

   if the pwm path exists
      use the pwm enable file to enable the fan

But shouldn't this branch be checking if the _pwm enable_ path exists, before setting it, and the enablePwm logic could be under its own conditional?

Done

Because pwm-fan driver doesn't export pwmX_enable attribute, I was skipping enable part if the pwm path from pwm-fan driver.

It looks like enablePwm() will just return when pwmX_enable not exist, so I have move enable part out.
This is really close, just a couple minor logic things that we need to resolve, then this should be good to go.  Sorry for not catching them the first time around.

Because this code isn't doing error handling with exceptions in its current form, you need to use the no throw overload of this, ie:

bool exists( const std::filesystem::path& p, std::error_code& ec ) noexcept;

Otherwise, there are cases where the path doesn't exist that will throw and crash the main EM executor.
